leatherbacks.Title: Leatherbacks Photo ID
leatherbacks.Project Description: That's my face! We will be using photo identification, citizen science, and Machine Learning (Artificial Intelligence) to better estimate critically endangered East Pacific leatherback sea turtle population size, internesting movements, migration patterns, fisheries interactions, and nesting behavior while simultaneously providing a platform for community outreach, fundraising, and conservation campaigns.
leatherbacks.Researcher profile: In August 2017 I graduated from Purdue University with a Masters of Science in Biology, and I received a Bachelors of Science in Marine Biology with a minor in Wildlife Conservation Biology from the University of Rhode Island in 2014. I have always wanted to have a career in endangered species conservation and ever since seeing my first photo of a leatherback sea turtles, I have been hooked - simply fascinated. At first I wanted to see one in person, then to work on various leatherback nesting beaches, then to receive my master's studying them, and now I work full time as a Marine Biologist and Leatherback Fellow for the Turtle Island Restoration Network. I spend my days determining how we can be more efficient in our study and conservation of this incredible species. Leatherbacks speciated around 110 million years, according to the fossil record. This means that leatherbacks were swimming around and thriviing in the same waters as the dinosaurs. Only now after persistent pressure from the human race are they facing extirpation from various ocean basins. They can dive deeper than many whale species (to 4000 feet!!!), are the largest reptile by weight, and eat ONLY jellyfish! Originally there were 8 distinct subpopulations of leatherbacks, but the one that occupied the South China Sea is already funcionally extinct. It is my goal not to lose another one! The East Pacific subpopulation only had an estimated 633 individuals in 2013 and is projected to experience a 99% population decline by 2040, making it one of the most endangered subpopulations of turtles in the entire world. At TIRN we are focusing our energies in this regionto make sure that we don't lose yet another subpopulation.
leatherbacks.Project impact: This project will allow us to keep track of the remaining individuals in this subpopulation and eventually all of the subpopulations. Conventional methods of individual identification are costly and require training, making it difificul to take advantage of all leatherback sightings for maximum data collection. Local fishermen or property owners viewing leatherbacks won't have an identification scanner or tag ready to partake in typical research practices. Simply taking a photo of the turtle and sending it to the photo ID database be sufficient for gaining valuable population data! If a fisherman catches a turtle in his or her gear and is able to simply take a photo, we can understand what region the turtle nests in! If the turtle has passed, we will know what rookery has lost a precious adult female. We will distribute these GoPros to all the leatherback nesting projects in the East Pacific to facilitate their contribution to the database.Not only will this photo ID database help us to fill in important population-wide data gaps, but it will also provide a platform for fundraising, community involvement, and public awareness.
leatherbacks.When do you need equipment delivered by?: The equipment needs to be delivered before October and the website design completed by March 2019
leatherbacks.When does the project start?: The project will begin in October 2018 and continue indefinitely
leatherbacks.How long will the project run for?: This project will be an accumulation of individual turtle photos that hopefully, as the population continues to grow, will be indefinitely growing and expanding. The hope is that this project eventually includes leatherbacks from all ocean basins and all major nesting grounds.
leatherbacks.If equipment is purchased for you, where: The budget savings from receiving purchases will go to supporting the salaries of on-the-ground local conservationists, and vital equipment for sea turtle population monitoring from Mexico-Ecuador.

salmon.Title: Coho Salmon Restoration Project
salmon.Project Description: This project will implement one of the largest restoration projects in the Lagunitas Creek Watershed, this project will restore 1 mile of stream habitat for endangered coho salmon and steelhead recovery, as well as for the benefit of other endnagered wildlife includeing CA freshwater shrimp and CA red-legged frogs.
salmon.Researcher profile: My name is Preston Brown, I have BS in Restoration Ecology from CO State Univ. My passion is restoring rivers and the species that depend on them, particularly pacific salmon and trout. This project is important to me becuase with such a large project comes a significant impact and a real chance at improving the habitat and survival of coho salmon and steelhead in the last stronghold for these fish in central CA. I beleive this project will make a differnece and have a significant benefit to the heallth of Lagunitas Creek and it's struggling salmon and steelhead populations.
salmon.Project impact: This project will address the limiting factors for salmon and steelhead survival in the region and will increase the area of floodplains/backwaters/sidechannels by 50% through the mile-long strech and removing 13K cu yards dirt and debris that was dumped in the creek cooridor decades ago. Adding these important habitat areas to the creek, and removing the debris and dirt from a former development will improve the abiltiy of the creek to behave naturally-unimpeded by hard man-made strucutres and will allow healthy habitats to be created and maintaned by a naturally-functioning creek.
salmon.When do you need equipment delivered by?: The dray suits and cameras are needed by August 13, 2018. The salaries are needed by December 2018.
salmon.When does the project start?: The project will begin in Aug 2018
salmon.How long will the project run for?: It will last just over one year, finishing in November of 2019
salmon.If equipment is purchased for you, where: The budget savings from receiving purchases will go to incresing the scope of the project, including adding more habitat features and strucutres, adding more plants to the restoration, and allow us to do more pre-post project monitoring.

microplastics.Title: Microplastics
microplastics.Project Description: This project will provide data for a comparison of oceanic microplastic concentrations between Cocos Island and Coastal areas in Costa Rica. We will pull “manta nets” behind our research vessels for set time frames and at set velocities, to determine the average concentration of microplastics in the surface waters. Many threatened and endangered marine species are filter feeders, meaning they indiscriminately swallow large quantities of water and filter out nutrient rich phytoplankton and algae. Studies have shown that filter feeds can be especially vulnerable to microplastics, as their body fats absorb high concentrations of toxic plastic byproducts. We will also sample beaches at the high tide line and the break zone for microplastics. We hope to bring attention to this issue at the pristine national park at Cocos Island, in an effort to encourage the already environmentally-conscious government of Costa Rica to decrease their utilization of single-use plastics.
microplastics.Researcher profile: Todd Steiner is the Execute Director and Founder of the Turtle Island Restoration Network. He has a MS in Biology and previously worked as a wildlife biologist at the South Florida Research Center, Everglades National Park, and radio-tracked the threatened indigo snake at Archbold Biological Field Station. He is currently involved in research and monitoring of endangered coho salmon and threatened steelhead in California, and initiated the an ongoing study of sea turtles at Cocos Island National Park. He has more than 40 years experience protecting and restoring endangered species and habitats, 11 years working and diving at Cocos Island (initiating 22 previous Cocos research expeditions), 41 years diving, 11 years tagging sharks and turtles. Todd is currently working on several different conservation projects at Cocos Island, but this would be the first study to focus on pollution at Cocos Island.
microplastics.Project impact: We hope to sample coastal and pristine island marine environments for micoplastic presence to evaluate spatial threats to marine species from plastic pollution. Our results will be used to encourage the Costa Rican government to increase plastic and pollution reduction measures.
microplastics.When do you need equipment delivered by?: The equipment needs to be delivered as soon as possible, as we will be attempting to collect samples in August 2018, but it is definitely needed by October 2018.
microplastics.When does the project start?: The project will begin in August 2018 and continue for two years.
microplastics.If equipment is purchased for you, where: The budget savings from receiving purchases will go towards increasing protection for the threatened and endangered shark and turtle species that occupy the Cocos Island National Park. We can use saved funds for satellite and acoustic tagging individuals to better undesrtsand their habitat use and ocean movements. As we learn more abouthot these species are using ocean habitats, we can better delineate no-take and closure zones in the East Pacific. We are in the process of creating the Cocos-Galapagos Swimway, a 95,000 square mile swath of marine protected area between Cocos Island and the Galapaos Islands. To do this we need to continue to gather evidence that endangered species use this migration cooridor as part of their regular movements.
